title: How do I dispute the dollar amount of a creditors claim in Chapter 7 non-asset adversay?
question: I'm in a chapter 7 adversary. Not surprisingly, this one particular creditor filed an adversary. The trustee has already filed his recommendation for discharge. My bankruptcy is a no-asset chapter 7 so this creditor did not have to file a proof of claim. I have documents to back up my assertion that their claim is fraudulent. I put this creditor on my petition, but with no amount (amount unknown) because I knew this very litigious person would try and block my discharge. I need to know how to make this creditor validate/substantiate the dollar amount of their claim (instead of just filing a complaint and trying to block my discharge) so that the court knows what's going on. Something like this can go all the way to trial if I don't do something about it now.
answers:
In an adversary you area allowed to ask for discovery. Demand all documentation that supports the claim in a document production request.
Demand in interrogatories that the creditor tell you why the creditor thinks you owe the creditor money.

I agree with the other attorneys that you will address the amount as part of your answer to their complaint. You may also conduct discovery as part of the adversary case. I think you should consult with a lawyer in your area. If you cannot afford to hire an attorney, perhaps he or she may give you advice on the important deadlines in your case for just a one-time fee for the consult.
Take the advice given - you need an experienced bankruptcy attorney to represent you in the adversary.

An Adversary Proceeding is civil litigation. That means that you can subpoena the plaintiff for a deposition, request a production of documents or answers to interrogatories. It also means that you must file and answer and that you must dispute the nondischargeability and or objection to discharge claims in a timely manner. You can state an affirmative defense. You can hold depositions with witnesses.

Sound complicated? It is and would likely be impossible to handle if you don't have an attorney. Find 2 or 3 bankruptcy litigation attorneys in your area, interview them and hire the one you think you can work with best.

This is also serious. If you do nothing or if you don't do the right things, the creditor will win and you will still owe them whatever they can prove you owe after the bankruptcy. You may also risk your complete discharge of debts.

The trustee does not 'recommend" discharge, but only states that he/she is no longer working on the case. This clears one hurdle for discharge but does not affect the Adversary Proceeding at all.
The previous answers are all good. This a very technical area of Federal Law. You need an attorney.

My colleagues are exactly right. Find/consult/hire a lawyer using the Avvo feature "Find a Lawyer". Make a list of 4-5 having many 5 star reviews from satisfied clients. If you don't get a prompt call back from one, go on to the next on your list. Some offer a free consultation by phone or in person.

There is nothing you can do to except answer the complaint and litigate each and every element of the complaint, including the amount of alleged damages. The creditor has a right to do this. Do not confuse the claims process with the adversary proceeding process. They are two different things. One dies not prohibit the other.

You can raise all your arguments as affirmative defenses to “inform the judge what’s going on”

How much is the creditor asking for?
You need to retain a bankruptcy lawyer who specializes in litigation to file an answer on your behalf. This is not something that you can do by yourself.

Sounds like a frustrating situation. Sorry to hear about it.

For other readers' benefit, an "adversary" is a trial that happens within a main bankruptcy case. They're rare, but they do happen, especially if one has a particularly aggressive creditor or the kind of claim that might survive a bankruptcy discharge. They're both legally and procedurally complex in most cases.

To put it simply, if you're in an adversary case, you're already in a situation where the creditor is asking to go to a trial and obtain a ruling in their favor in the bankruptcy court. If you don't want to go to get to that point, there are some motions that can be attempted (like a motion to dismiss or summary judgment) or you could try to reach a settlement agreement.

Unfortunately, whether any of those things would work or make sense depends heavily on the facts.

So this is the kind of situation where a lawyer's help are critical. Hoping for the best for you....
